item.title: Ticket #2017 (JavaScript for "rel" field in links references wrong id) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
While looking at another problem (#2016), I noticed that the Javascript "upit" function used for the Link options was throwing errors with almost every radio button click.

The problem: upit tries to assign a value to an object with id="rel", but no such object exists. Instead, it means to assign those values to id="link_rel".

The attached patch now avoids Javascript errors as well as correctly populating the "rel" field when one is creating or editing links.

item.title: edit-link-form.php.diff attached to Ticket #2016
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #2016 (Link edit radio buttons don't work) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
The link edit radio buttons should have the same name, but for the target and visible selections, they don't.

My patch adds in the correct names ("link_target" and "link_visible", respectively).

This fixes the error mentioned here: ​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-testers/2005-December/001176.html

item.title: Ticket #2014 (Filters not applied to bloginfo_rss()) created
item.dc:creator: Kafkaesqui
item.description:
Currently bloginfo_rss() lacks a filter hook: 

function bloginfo_rss($show = '') {
	echo get_bloginfo_rss($show);
}

It should probably be more like: 

function bloginfo_rss($show = '') {
	$info = get_bloginfo_rss($show);
	$info = apply_filters('bloginfo_rss', $info, $show);
	echo $info;
}

item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
The i18n code in the new code needs major review. As reported there are many tags within localizable strings, some unlocalized strings and formatting isssues (for example in many places (s)printf should be used to insert parameters to loaliziable strings)

Here are patches for:

wp-admin/import/blogger.php wp-admin/import/textpattern.php

They also need review :))

I hope tomorrow to put some effort on plugins. Please refer any discussion to wp-polyglots mailing list.

item.description: If you really insist on eliminating evals, rewrite the PHP that constructs the string vars so that it constructs a multidimensional array, then use the argument (n) to locate the correct array element. IMO this is a waste of time as the script is already very light.

item.title: Ticket #2002 (Gratuitous abuse of JavaScript's eval() function) closed
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description:
invalid:

Eval is a necessary evil in this circumstance because we are building a var name, not a string, and we need the value of that var name. This diff breaks the script.

item.title: Ticket #1997 (Trackback field populated with 'Array' When Editing a Draft) updated
item.dc:creator: abhay
item.description:
The only thing that I can guess is that an array somehow got into the to_ping column of one of your posts. How it got there is beyond me. The fact that it went away is not terribly surprising because it was probably parsed, pinged and then concatenated to the pinged column.

What I wonder is how it got there.

item.title: Ticket #2004 (Pages page should page) created
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: For people that have > 100 pages listing them all doesn't make much sense. We should improve this by offering paging for more than 50 and also search.

item.title: Ticket #2003 (Permalinks fail when using the same permalinks and category base) created
item.dc:creator: amanzi
item.description:
If you set the category base the same as the permalinks, when clicking on a single post, all posts are displayed.

If that doesn't make sense try these two setups and test:

  1. Permalinks: /archives/%post_id%

Category base: /archives

  1. Permalinks: /tags/%category%/%postname%/

Category base: /tags

With either of the above set up, clicking on a single post displays all posts - as if you were on the index.php page.

item.title: inline-uploading.diff attached to Ticket #2002

item.description: Patch-1.0

item.title: Ticket #2002 (Gratuitous abuse of JavaScript's eval() function) created
item.dc:creator: h3h
item.description:
See: ​http://xkr.us/js/eval

Some of the JS on the inline-uploading.php page was written without understanding of what eval() is or does. It is not necessary for string concatenation in the least and is instead very costly.

item.title: Ticket #1997 (Trackback field populated with 'Array' When Editing a Draft) updated

item.description: Abhay... I have no idea. Really. It baffles me.

item.title: Ticket #2001 (Permalink options page lacks syntax or formatting instructions) created
item.dc:creator: h3h
item.description:
The Customize Permalinks page has 4 options. The "Default" setting leaves the "Custom structure" box blank, but the box stays blank if one chooses the "Custom" radio button.

There are no syntactical or formatting instructions anywhere on the page as there are in WP 1.5.

The user has no easy way (opening the Codex in a new window and looking up variables is *not* easy) of knowing that the "Custom structure" box should contain something like "/%postname%/" unless he/she incidentally clicks on one of the other radio buttons, and then it's only by a means of reasoning.

This needs to be spelled out as it is in 1.5, giving an example of a "Custom structure format" directly above or below the box itself, making clear that one should start with "/..." and not "​http://mysite.com/..." as well as the most common variables (%year%, %monthnum%, %day, %postname%, etc.).

I'll create a patch if no one else is willing.

item.title: Ticket #1955 (Outgoing trackback ping could include 'charset' attribute for ...) updated
item.dc:creator: matopc
item.description:
I modified wp-trackback.php to parse charset parameter in the request header. Below codes need to be verified, works for me though. Thank you.

/wp-trackback.php, lines 33- 

$tb_url    = $_POST['url'];
$title     = $_POST['title'];
$excerpt   = $_POST['excerpt'];
$blog_name = $_POST['blog_name'];
$charset   = $_POST['charset'];
if ($charset)
	$charset = strtoupper( trim($charset) );
else
	$charset = 'ASCII, UTF-8, ISO-8859-1, JIS, EUC-JP, SJIS';

change to 

$tb_url    = $_POST['url'];
$title     = $_POST['title'];
$excerpt   = $_POST['excerpt'];
$blog_name = $_POST['blog_name'];
$headers = apache_request_headers();
$charset = stristr ($headers['Content-Type'], 'charset=');
if ($charset) {
    $charset = (strpos ($charset, ';')) ? substr ($charset, 8, (strpos($charset, ';') - 8)) : substr ($charset, 8);
    $charset = strtoupper (trim ($charset));
    } else {
    $charset = 'ASCII, UTF-8, ISO-8859-1, JIS, EUC-JP, SJIS';
    }

item.title: tooSmall.png attached to Ticket #1998
item.dc:creator: tysontate
item.description: Screenshot of problem.

item.title: Ticket #1998 ("Size of the post box" input box too small) created
item.dc:creator: tysontate
item.description:
On MacOS X 10.4.3 using Safari 2.0.2, the input text area for the "Size of the post box" input in Options -> Writing is too narrow. In Firefox 1.5, it fits "10" just fine, however.

This is my first ticket (sorry if I break any "rules"!) so I'm not exactly sure how to create a diff/patch, but the change is pretty easy: Change the "size" attribute of the input box from 2 to 3 or 4.

item.title: Changeset [3252]: Don't attempt to match the index against a rule. This fixes problems ...

item.description: Don't attempt to match the index against a rule. This fixes problems with /index.php requests matching agagainst the %category% rewrite rules.
